00045 
00046 
00047 /******************************************************************
00048 This class enables you to visit each and every member of an array
00049 exactly once in an apparently random order.
00050 
00051 An application of this algorithim would be a good pixel fade in/fade out
00052 where each pixel of the frame buffer was set to black one at a time.
00053 
00054 Here's how you would implement a pixel fade using this class:
00055 
00056 void FadeToBlack(Screen *screen)
00057 {
00058         int w = screen.GetWidth();
00059         int h = screen.GetHeight();
00060 
00061         int pixels = w * h;
00062 
00063         PrimeSearch search(pixels);
00064 
00065         int p;
00066 
00067         while((p=search.GetNext())!=-1)
00068         {
00069                 int x = p % w;
00070                 int y = h / p;
00071 
00072                 screen.SetPixel(x, y, BLACK);
00073 
00074                 // of course, you wouldn't blit every pixel change.
00075                 screen.Blit();
00076         }
00077 }
00078 
00079 
00080 NOTE: If you want the search to start over at the beginning again - 
00081 you must call the Restart() method, OR call GetNext(true).
00082 
00083 ********************************************************************/
00084 
00085 
00086 class PrimeSearch
00087 {
00088         static int prime_array[];
00089 
00090         int skip;
00091         int currentPosition;
00092         int maxElements;
00093         int *currentPrime;
00094         int searches;
00095         
00096 public:
00097         PrimeSearch(int elements);
00098         int GetNext(bool restart=false);
00099         bool Done() { return (searches==*currentPrime); }
00100         void Restart() { currentPosition=0; searches=0; }
00101 };
